overview_of_class:
In MSE 316-2, students will learn about principles underlying diffusional phase transformations and the dynamical development of microstructure in solids. Lectures, and laboratory.

A student completing this course will be able to:

1) Discuss fundamental concepts and physical laws used to describe the thermodynamics and kinetics of diffusional phase transformations, including
classical nucleation theory (CNT) in unary and binary systems
the theory of spinodal decomposition (SD),
the theory of diffusion controlled precipitate growth,
the theory of interface instability,
the Lifschitz-Slyozow-Wagner (LSW) theory of coarsening,
and the Johnson-Mehl-Avrami-Kolmogorov (JMAK) theory of the time dependence of diffusional phase transformations
2) Discuss the impact of temperature, composition, interfacial free energy, strain, curvature, and defects in solids on equilibrium and non-equilibrium processes in the context of these theories.
3) Predict the stability of phases, the magnitude of barriers opposing phase transformation, critical and other characteristic length scales, and the kinetics of diffusional phase transformations from thermodynamic data.
name: Microstructural Dynamics
